channel.title: Java, can anyone here explain their experiences?
channel.description:
First of all, sorry for the length but I don't know how to give a brief summary of this. I'm all over the place with it.
So I want to learn java. I've gotten into it at least ten times. I learn some stuff, but I never actually learn how to apply it. And I just want to know, when you guys were learning java how did you actually practice it? Because it never tells me how to really apply it. Like HelloWorld. These books tell me the code but they never explain it in depth. I can't figure out how to apply it to my own sample code for practice if I don't know what the entire code structure is for.
public static void main(String[] args) {
How am I supposed to apply this to my own application, when I don't understand why there's [] next to String? Or how am I supposed to know when functions are capitalized or not? I've seen it written as string and String. Or how am I supposed to apply this when nothing is telling me why the args has to be there? Why does it have to be public and not private? I can't modify this code if I don't understand it which means I can't practice it for more understanding. The only thing I can do to it is change it from sayin hello world to blah blah. That doesn't mean I learned anything from it.
Basically, the way I'm learning this doesn't help me. It's like learning math. I know that 5^-1 is 1/5 but no one ever gave me a reason for why that actually is true they just said its always 1/n. so I can easily repeat that. 6^-1=1/6. 100^-1=1/100. But I can't expand on my knowledge if I don't understand why that's true. Being able to repeat something doesn't mean you understand it.
Again, sorry for this long ramble. I really want to learn java I just can't figure it out and it irritates me.

item.source: Java, can anyone here explain their experiences?

item.title: Java, can anyone here explain their experiences?
item.dc:creator: @Protosstribe object
item.description:
@Protosstribe wrote:

I buy a lot of books and read the parts I am currently interested in, saving the rest for later. Then I usually apply what I learn from them in practice. But, I usually never write the examples from the books that have any, because I prefer to read the theory and think on my own. Before I write any code, I usually think about sound architecture and design. That also includes following any of the well known principles (for instance KISS (Keep It Simple, Stupid), low coupling and high cohesion, SoC (Separation of Concerns), IoC (Inversion of Control) and SOLID (Single responsibility principle, Open-closed principle, Liskov substitution principle, Interface segregation principle and Dependency inversion principle)).

All the above might not be relevant to you right now. But if you continue and practice you’ll eventually find it relevant at some point in the future. However, I can recommend a book called Introduction to Java Programming (9:th Edition) by Y. Daniel Liang. I have the 7:th Edition. It’s a thick book that covers all you need to know right now.

Currently I have 76 books in programming languages (and other kinds of natural languages for that matter) in my shelf. All ranging from primer books to advanced ones (compiler theory (and language transformation in general), program analysis, neural networks, reverse engineering, computer forensics and malware analysis, OS design and general program architecture and design). If you are interested in any specific area, perhaps I could recommend some more books. I have books within “most” areas.

Read full topic
item.source: Java, can anyone here explain their experiences?

item.title: Java, can anyone here explain their experiences?
item.dc:creator: @Tree Tree
item.description:
@Tree wrote:

  1. Read tutorial.
  2. View example.
  3. Modify example.
  4. Write own version of the example.
  5. Make it more efficient and nit pick.
  6. Save and journal everything.
  7. Repeat it.

Docs are your friend. A mentor is also helpful, as well as a personal project. A simple IRC bot is a nice starting point.

Then pick something new and do the same.

Read full topic

item.title: Java, can anyone here explain their experiences?
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

sinisoul:

Eventually it all clicks. I think learning how to have good designs was the hardest bit.

I would say that learning by example versus lecture versus book is definitely up to each individual, but it’s incredibly difficult and impossible to become a professional programmer without reading about design patterns. Good for mentioning this, it’s often overlooked. Many people seem to miss the other half of software engineering.

Read full topic

start making things on eclipse by your own, idk try to make a program that prints the first 100 fibonacci numbers… idk, just start with little things, and if you have any problems you can always ask somone.
I’ve started with runescape private servers, but i realized that learning by them is a REALLY BAD PRACTICE, that doesn’t mean that you shouldn’t do private servers, but if you start with them it could bring you some bad habits.

item.title: Java, can anyone here explain their experiences?
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“wildskiller, post:23, topic:522487”][quote author=Ambokile link=topic=640989.msg4318712#msg4318712 date=1371907941]
The [] creates an array of strings, and this is to hold the arguments supplied to the program. An array holds multiple objects of the same type, and so multiple string objects (words, mainly) can be supplied to give multiple arguments.
[/quote]
An array can hold multiple objects of any type, depending on what you’ve applied to the instance of the array.

Object[] would take an array of different, or the same, objects.
String[] would take the same object, which is strings.

Just felt like I had to correct ya.[/quote]You didn’t actually correct him, he was right. An Object[] array still contains only Objects, even if different types of objects are there. Just like all squares are rectangles but not all rectangles are square So you’re both correct, really.

Read full topic
item.source: Java, can anyone here explain their experiences?

item.title: Java, can anyone here explain their experiences?
item.dc:creator: @wildskiller wildskiller
item.description:
@wildskiller wrote:

Ambokile:

The [] creates an array of strings, and this is to hold the arguments supplied to the program. An array holds multiple objects of the same type, and so multiple string objects (words, mainly) can be supplied to give multiple arguments.

An array can hold multiple objects of any type, depending on what you’ve applied to the instance of the array.

Object[] would take an array of different, or the same, objects.
String[] would take the same object, which is strings.

Just felt like I had to correct ya.

Read full topic

item.description:
@eyeownyew wrote:

I messed around with private servers for years, then when I got bored of that I started to make projects of my own. This was a nice approach for me because it made everything relatable, and due to curiosity (wondering how servers, clients, graphics, etc function in Java), I never ran out of anything to research

item.source: Java, can anyone here explain their experiences?

item.title: Java, can anyone here explain their experiences?
item.dc:creator: @Lin Lin
item.description:
@Lin wrote:

[quote=“tigerclan, post:11, topic:522487”][quote author=Lin link=topic=640989.msg4318904#msg4318904 date=1371951617]

Don’t learn by the books. Look at code that does something you want and start by copying it or doing something similar. This is how I learned just about everything I know.

Is this sarcastic or not?
[/quote]It’s legitimate. I know it sounds bad, but this way you learn first what you’re learning can be applied to and can apply it once you actually understand it. If you only go with what books have, you’re limited to what you’ve read vs what experience you and others have. Almost all of my first Java knowledge came from just looking at private servers and adding new content by copying what was already written.

Personally I think this is very bad. You’re basically learning how to use features without learning the reason why. You need a more in depth analysis to fully understand what you’re doing.[/quote]No you’re not. By applying code that someone else has written, you’re learning what the code does and know why everything in it is used. Just because don’t understand it initially doesn’t mean you never will. Look at where doing that got me. [size=1pt]inb4 nowhere or negative comment regarding my boolean scripting skills[/size] Same thing goes for many other programmers who officially started a programming hobby here by getting involved in RuneScape private servers.

Read full topic
item.source: Java, can anyone here explain their experiences?

item.title: Java, can anyone here explain their experiences?
item.dc:creator: @kicker862 kicker862
item.description:
@kicker862 wrote:

Would it be bad if I had just read through a handful of books first and then tried to apply what I picked up from all of them? Because I feel like I’m just trying to get ahead of myself.
You guys reference RSPS.
I started out with RSPS which is what even sparked my interest in java. I didn’t do really unique things to it though. I pretty much just renamed it to what I wanted and added a customs pack and changed the sprites. All of which I had done by copying code off of here. The hardest thing I think I did was add a server control panel, which I still had just copied from the tutorial section.
But I still don’t think I could achieve any of the things I did without having to copy someones code. How long should you even be copying snippets for before you’re writing your own?

Read full topic
item.source: Java, can anyone here explain their experiences?

item.title: Java, can anyone here explain their experiences?
item.dc:creator: @tigerclan tigerclan
item.description:
@tigerclan wrote:

[quote=“Lin, post:9, topic:522487”][quote author=Bowser jr link=topic=640989.msg4318793#msg4318793 date=1371925781]

Don’t learn by the books. Look at code that does something you want and start by copying it or doing something similar. This is how I learned just about everything I know.

Is this sarcastic or not?
[/quote]It’s legitimate. I know it sounds bad, but this way you learn first what you’re learning can be applied to and can apply it once you actually understand it. If you only go with what books have, you’re limited to what you’ve read vs what experience you and others have. Almost all of my first Java knowledge came from just looking at private servers and adding new content by copying what was already written.[/quote]

Personally I think this is very bad. You’re basically learning how to use features without learning the reason why. You need a more in depth analysis to fully understand what you’re doing.

Read full topic
item.source: Java, can anyone here explain their experiences?

item.title: Java, can anyone here explain their experiences?
item.dc:creator: @xEthanx xEthanx
item.description:
@xEthanx wrote:

I would suggest watching a skilled friend while he’s coding with some sort of screen sharing software. I was in a very similar situation to you, as I was poor in areas of application with Java.

But during our current RSPS we’re working on, I just started to watch him code through screen sharing and watching as he wrote things out. I think you’ll find that understand a piece of code is much easier than constructing it yourself, at least that’s how it was for me.

Anyways, after watching for a long time I just became more familiar with what certain things meant.

Read full topic
item.source: Java, can anyone here explain their experiences?
